document.docAuthor: Magalhães, Wagner F., Bailey-Brock, Julie & Watling, Les
document.docTitle: Magelona anuheone Magalhães & Bailey-Brock & Watling 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Four new species of Magelona (Annelida: Magelonidae) from Easter Island, Guam and Hawaii

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Four new species of Magelona (Annelida: Magelonidae) from Easter Island, Guam and Hawaii

subSubSection.paragraph: Material examined . Holotype : Easter Island, Hanga Roa, 27°08'45.60" S , 109°26'06.00" W , Sta. HB3, 5 November 2015 , coll. L. Watling ( USNM 1494162). Paratypes : Easter Island, same date and collector as holotype : Vare Vare, Sta. Bajo B4 (1 af, USNM 1494163); Vare Vare, Sta. Ariba A3 (4 af, SCBUCN-7281; 1 af, MNHNCL ANN-15018; 1 af, MNHNCL ANN-15019; 1 af, MNHNCL ANN-15020). Additional material examined. Hanga Roa, Sta. HB3 (1 af); Sta. Ariba A1 (1 af); Vare Vare, Sta. Ariba 1 (1 af); Sta. Ariba 2 (1 af); Sta. Ariba 3 (1); Ariba 4 (6 af and 1 pf); Sta. Ariba 5 (3 af); Sta. Bajo B1 (3 af); Sta. Bajo B2 (3 af); Sta. Bajo B3 (2 af); Sta. Bajo B5 (4 af and 1 pf).

Diagnosis. Prostomium much longer than wide, with distinct prostomial horns. Notopodia of chaetigers 1‒8 with elongate postchaetal lamellae with minutely crenulate upper edges. Low, rounded pre-chaetal lamellae. Superior processes present from chaetigers 1‒8. Thoracic chaetae simple bilimbate capillaries. Abdominal hooded hooks tridentate. Lateral pouches (Ʃ configuration) present between chaetigers nine and ten.

Description. Holotype : incomplete posteriorly; prostomium 1.84 mm long, 1.14 mm wide; thorax 8.3 mm long (including prostomium), 0.61 mm wide; abdomen 0.79 mm wide; total length 26.4 mm for 45 chaetigers. Four paratypes measured, all posteriorly incomplete; prostomium 0.84‒1.05 mm long, 0.63‒0.8 mm wide; thorax 3.97‒5.3 mm long (including prostomium), 0.36‒0.43 mm wide; abdomen 0.35‒0.45 mm wide; total length 13.4‒24.5 mm for 31‒61 chaetigers.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7. A–C,
M. cf. symmetrica
, A, prostomium stained with shirlastain A; B and C, MGSP, dorsal and ventral views, respectively, with arrows indicating distinctive staining regions of thorax and abdomen; D–F,
M. anuheone
sp. nov.
, D, prostomium of holotype stained with shirlastain A; E and F, MGSP of holotype, dorsal and ventral views, respectively, with arrows indicating distinctive staining regions of thorax and abdomen.

FIGURE 8.
Magelona anuheone
sp. nov.
A, anterior end and thoracic region, dorsal view of holotype; B, anterior region, ventral view of holotype; C, thoracic simple bilimbate capillaries; D, tridentate abdominal hooded hooks, lateral and frontal views respectively; E, parapodium of chaetiger 3, anterior view; F, parapodium of chaetiger 7, anterior view; G, parapodium of chaetiger 8, anterior view; H, parapodium of chaetiger 9, anterior view; I, parapodium of chaetiger 10, anterior view; J, parapodium of chaetiger 12, anterior view; K, posterior end and pygidium with anal cirri. Abbreviations: ch, chaetiger; lp, lateral pouch; pa, palp; ph, prostomial horn; pr, prostomium; bo, burrowing organ.

subSubSection.paragraph: All preserved specimens lacking pigmentation, pale yellow.

Reproduction. Holotype an ovigerous female with eggs present in body cavity. Eggs densely packed from chaetiger 48. Eggs become larger along the body reaching about 65 µm in diameter from chaetiger 55.

Remarks.
Magelona anuheone
sp. nov. , belongs to a small group of five species (
M. berkeleyi
,
M. cornuta
,
M. montera Mortimer, Cassà, Martin & Gil, 2012
,
M. nonatoi Bolívar & Lana, 1986
, and
M. tehuanensis
Hernandez- Alcantra & Solis-Weiss, 2000 ) all sharing the following characters: 1) prostomium with frontal horns; 2) distally crenulate notopodial lateral lamellae; 3) chaetiger nine possessing only winged capillaries, and 4) tridentate abdominal hooks.
Magelona berkeleyi
and
M. nonatoi
have rudimentary prostomial horns whereas the new species,
M. montera , M. tehuanensis
, and
M. cornuta
have well-developed frontal horns.
Magelona cornuta
and
M. tehuanensis
have a crenulated margin of the prostomium and the new species
M. anuheone
sp. nov. and
Magelona montera
have a smooth margin of the prostomium and distinct bulbous horns.

Although several species have been described with anteriorly open pouches, only
M. parochilis Zhou & Mortimer, 2013
also lack modified chaetae on chaetiger 9. It differs from
M. anuheone
sp. nov. on the segmental origin of the open pouches (in between chaetigers 9/ 10 in
M. anuheone
and chaetiger 11/ 12 in
M. parochilis
), and by having a rounded prostomium without prostomial horns.

Etymology. The new species epithet derives from the Rapa Nui language and is a combination of anuhe (caterpillar) and one (sand). The implied meaning being ‘caterpillar of the sand’ and the new name was chosen by Sergio Rapu from Rapa Nui (Easter Island).
Distribution. This species is only known from shallow waters of Easter Island, Southeastern Pacific Ocean.
